intro: Amygdalus grata, commonly known as the sweet almond tree, is a species native to the Middle East and parts of southern Europe. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters, featuring a rounded crown and lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, white or pinkish flowers in early spring, which are followed by the development of almond-like fruits. The seeds inside the fruit are edible and are widely used in culinary and cosmetic applications. Its botanical characteristics make it an important species in both horticulture and agriculture.
